description:
â€œPeople like to say â€˜go virtualâ€™ like itâ€™s an easy thing. But let me tell you - itâ€™s not that easy to do. 

Iâ€™ve been a live-events emcee and planner for over 30 years. What I like most about the job is the energy from the audience that fuels me when I am on stage. The music, the lights, the laughter and the applause. I havenâ€™t had any of that since February 2020 when all the jobs dried up.

The first chance I had to go virtual was when a client whom I had worked with for years called me to manage and host a virtual event for them in October 2020. 

Easy? Nothing is easy. I realised that the amount of prep work needed to produce a successful virtual event, is just as much as a physical event.

It involved live-video streaming from 17 countries. We really didnâ€™t know what to expect. We were operating out of a makeshift studio with minimal IT equipment. We faced huge technical difficulties, connection issues and co-ordination challenges in countries where the first language was not English. We got through by the skin of our teeth. But on that job, I learnt so much.

With that experience as a showcase of sorts, I managed and hosted several more virtual events. Each one gets easier and more enjoyable.

The foundation of a virtual event is the technology, so organisers really need to work with very strong tech partners. I partner a company called Odyssey Concepts, which uses a state-of-the-art green-screen studio to cater to the virtual events market.

I still miss the energy from a live audience. But this is the new reality. And I take comfort that even though I cannot see them, they send me comments after the show to say that they really enjoyed what I did! At the end of the day, all I want to do is entertain, even if itâ€™s through a screen.â€

- Moe Alkaff, veteran events planner, emcee and entertainer

@moealkaff8 #SGPerspectives #Govsg

The first chance I had to go virtual was when a client whom I had worked with for years called me to manage and host a virtual event for them in October 2020. 

Easy? Nothing is easy. I realised that the amount of prep work needed to produce a successful virtual event, is just as much as a physical event.

It involved live-video streaming from 17 countries. We really didnt know what to expect. We were operating out of a makeshift studio with minimal IT equipment. We faced huge technical difficulties, connection issues and co-ordination challenges in countries where the first language was not English. We got through by the skin of our teeth. But on that job, I learnt so much.

With that experience as a showcase of sorts, I managed and hosted several more virtual events. Each one gets easier and more enjoyable.

The foundation of a virtual event is the technology, so organisers really need to work with very strong tech partners. I partner a company called Odyssey Concepts, which uses a state-of-the-art green-screen studio to cater to the virtual events market.

I still miss the energy from a live audience. But this is the new reality. And I take comfort that even though I cannot see them, they send me comments after the show to say that they really enjoyed what I did! At the end of the day, all I want to do is entertain, even if its through a screen.

description:
Merdeka!
.
60 years ago, this day, 3 June 1959, marked a new chapter in Singaporeâ€™s history. ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬
.
Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew made the proclamation of Singapore as a self-governing state.
.
Addressing a huge rally at the Padang, Mr Lee announced that he had been asked by his party to lead the government as prime minister. The new government would take office formally on 5 June 1959.
.
It was also on this day that he made the electrifying call-to-action, â€œMerdeka!"
.
#todayinhistory #singaporehistory #LeeKuanYew #merdekageneration
description_Translated:
Merdeka!
.
60 years ago, this day, 3 June 1959, marked a new chapter in Singapores history. 
.
Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew made the proclamation of Singapore as a self-governing state.
.
Addressing a huge rally at the Padang, Mr Lee announced that he had been asked by his party to lead the government as prime minister. The new government would take office formally on 5 June 1959.
.
It was also on this day that he made the electrifying call-to-action, Merdeka!"
.

description:
â€œIâ€™m actually not surprised that I had gotten the virus, but I do understand that with the vaccination, I will be in a safe state. For most (fully vaccinated) people â€“ about 98% will recover with mild or no symptoms. For them, the Home Recovery Programme would be ideal. 

 I was able to work from home, connect with my co-workers, and also spend a lot more time having â€œme timeâ€, doing things that I like. 

Iâ€™m feeling as good as before. If you are eligible for the vaccine, I would recommend to take it as soon as possible to build a defense against the virus. Even if youâ€™re vaccinated, I would suggest you to avoid crowded places, practice social distancing and step up on your personal hygiene. Protect yourself and your loved ones.â€

â€“ Felix Siow, 42, Healthcare Manager #SGPerspectives

Watch his full story here: go.gov.sg/sgpp-fs-ig (link in bio)
description_Translated:
Im actually not surprised that I had gotten the virus, but I do understand that with the vaccination, I will be in a safe state. For most (fully vaccinated) people  about 98% will recover with mild or no symptoms. For them, the Home Recovery Programme would be ideal. 

 I was able to work from home, connect with my co-workers, and also spend a lot more time having me time, doing things that I like. 

Im feeling as good as before. If you are eligible for the vaccine, I would recommend to take it as soon as possible to build a defense against the virus. Even if youre vaccinated, I would suggest you to avoid crowded places, practice social distancing and step up on your personal hygiene. Protect yourself and your loved ones.

 Felix Siow, 42, Healthcare Manager #SGPerspectives

description:
â€œIn my seven years volunteering at the Thekchen Choling temple, last yearâ€™s Vesak Day celebrations was the biggest hurdle we had to overcome. The Circuit Breaker period caught us all off guard as we had to ensure that the celebrations could continue safely and plan for a virtual event. 

Thankfully, the temple had already started minor upgrades to its IT systems around 4 years ago and we invested in buying new AV equipment. We also revamped our website which allowed for online registration for events. You could say it was good timing as that system had only been running for just 6 months before the Circuit Breaker period!

Various messaging platforms were also used to broadcast important announcements for the event. As many of our devotees are seniors, we made sure they received help to register for the event via our telephone helpline. 

Our nuns, monks and volunteers all banded together to make sure the event ran smoothly. After the event, some of our senior nuns started to broadcast daily prayers live and continued to use the direct messaging platforms to stay connected with our devotees. 

Many devotees still miss the physical connection of being in the temple. We plan to increase the temple floor space to accommodate more devotees while maintaining safe distancing and have made further improvements to our IT infrastructure. 

While we hope to eventually be able to welcome our devotees back to the temple, we know that the situation is unpredictable and are ready to pivot our operations to the online space. 

From this experience, Iâ€™ve learnt that we need to be mindful of the different age groups when making the transition to digital platforms. It is easy to assume that everyone is savvy enough to follow, but that is never always the case. We must keep a look out for those who may have difficulties and go the extra mile to help them. This is what it means to be stronger together.â€ 

- Vincent Kessler, 40, volunteer at Thekchen Choling Tibetan Buddhist temple #SGPerspectives
description_Translated:
In my seven years volunteering at the Thekchen Choling temple, last years Vesak Day celebrations was the biggest hurdle we had to overcome. The Circuit Breaker period caught us all off guard as we had to ensure that the celebrations could continue safely and plan for a virtual event. 

Thankfully, the temple had already started minor upgrades to its IT systems around 4 years ago and we invested in buying new AV equipment. We also revamped our website which allowed for online registration for events. You could say it was good timing as that system had only been running for just 6 months before the Circuit Breaker period!

Various messaging platforms were also used to broadcast important announcements for the event. As many of our devotees are seniors, we made sure they received help to register for the event via our telephone helpline. 

Our nuns, monks and volunteers all banded together to make sure the event ran smoothly. After the event, some of our senior nuns started to broadcast daily prayers live and continued to use the direct messaging platforms to stay connected with our devotees. 

Many devotees still miss the physical connection of being in the temple. We plan to increase the temple floor space to accommodate more devotees while maintaining safe distancing and have made further improvements to our IT infrastructure. 

While we hope to eventually be able to welcome our devotees back to the temple, we know that the situation is unpredictable and are ready to pivot our operations to the online space. 

From this experience, Ive learnt that we need to be mindful of the different age groups when making the transition to digital platforms. It is easy to assume that everyone is savvy enough to follow, but that is never always the case. We must keep a look out for those who may have difficulties and go the extra mile to help them. This is what it means to be stronger together. 

- Vincent Kessler, 40, volunteer at Thekchen Choling Tibetan Buddhist temple #SGPerspectives

description:
âš ï¸ This post contains anecdotes from an individual bereaved by a suicide death. If you need support, visit www.pleasestaymovement.com or approach these helplines: go.gov.sg/suicide-helplines
 
â€œSadly, many parents fail to understand that young people can suffer from mental health issues. They donâ€™t realise that society has changed tremendously. So in 2019, a group of bereaved mothers & I started the PleaseStay.Movement to raise awareness of youth suicide & share about the loss we suffered. 
 
When COVID-19 hit in 2020, we had youths reaching out to us for help through FB. A couple of teenagers shared with us that they felt life was no longer worth living. We offered them words of comfort & directed them to seek professional help. These cases may seem extreme, but they spoke volumes on how the pandemic had a huge impact on mental health.
 
Young people are becoming more conscious of how they present themselves due to their exposure to social media. Similarly, the peer pressure they experience is much stronger than what we used to face. I remember once when my child didnâ€™t do well in his exam, he cried because he felt he wasnâ€™t good enough. I told him that I didnâ€™t compare him with other children & that I was content so long as he did his best. Despite this assurance, the tragedy still happened because he couldnâ€™t come to terms with his academic performance & societal pressures. I believe this is something parents need to be mindful of as we live in a rapidly changing society. They may need to relook at their parenting skills & show more empathy so that they can communicate with their children effectively.
 
As a community, we need to be more empathetic, & play a part to show love & care for the people around us. Weâ€™ve heard stories of how certain actions can drive a person to suicide. Sometimes, all anyone needs is just a hug or pat on the shoulder when they going through tough times. If you encounter someone looking like they are not their usual self, just ask them how they are feeling. Little things like that lets them know there is someone who cares for them.â€
 
â€“ Doreen Kho, 46, housewife & co-founder of the â€˜PleaseStay.Movementâ€™
#MentalHealth #SGPerspectives
description_Translated:
This post contains anecdotes from an individual bereaved by a suicide death. If you need support, visit www.pleasestaymovement.com or approach these helplines: go.gov.sg/suicide-helplines
 
Sadly, many parents fail to understand that young people can suffer from mental health issues. They dont realise that society has changed tremendously. So in 2019, a group of bereaved mothers & I started the PleaseStay.Movement to raise awareness of youth suicide & share about the loss we suffered. 
 
When COVID-19 hit in 2020, we had youths reaching out to us for help through FB. A couple of teenagers shared with us that they felt life was no longer worth living. We offered them words of comfort & directed them to seek professional help. These cases may seem extreme, but they spoke volumes on how the pandemic had a huge impact on mental health.
 
Young people are becoming more conscious of how they present themselves due to their exposure to social media. Similarly, the peer pressure they experience is much stronger than what we used to face. I remember once when my child didnt do well in his exam, he cried because he felt he wasnt good enough. I told him that I didnt compare him with other children & that I was content so long as he did his best. Despite this assurance, the tragedy still happened because he couldnt come to terms with his academic performance & societal pressures. I believe this is something parents need to be mindful of as we live in a rapidly changing society. They may need to relook at their parenting skills & show more empathy so that they can communicate with their children effectively.
 
As a community, we need to be more empathetic, & play a part to show love & care for the people around us. Weve heard stories of how certain actions can drive a person to suicide. Sometimes, all anyone needs is just a hug or pat on the shoulder when they going through tough times. If you encounter someone looking like they are not their usual self, just ask them how they are feeling. Little things like that lets them know there is someone who cares for them.
 
 Doreen Kho, 46, housewife & co-founder of the PleaseStay.Movement
#MentalHealth #SGPerspectives

description:
â€œIâ€™ve been in HR for most of my professional life. 

My career trajectory took a detour when I left my HR job in 2019 to move to China for 6 months with my family. We wanted to spend quality time before my son started formal primary education, experience a different culture, and also improve my Mandarin.

It wasnâ€™t an easy decision. I was concerned about our finances, my career, and if I could find a suitable job when we returned. My hands trembled when I handed in my resignation letter.

In China, I doubled down on networking efforts via online platforms. I took up online courses and volunteered with professional HR bodies.

It made all the difference when I returned. The CEO of an education technology company whom I knew contacted me about a HR leadership advisory role. But he also wanted me to head up digital marketing efforts.

This was completely new for me. I went for a Professional Conversion Programme with QED Consulting where I learnt about SEO, analytics, and using digital channels to create brand awareness.

I realised how important networking is in oneâ€™s career. Nurture networks early, even before we need it. 

Learning is lifelong. You can pivot to other roles, even at a late age. 

You are always in control of your career.â€

- Martin Lee, in his 40s, Snr HR Advisor, Director of Partnerships at Edtech firm, The Amdon Group 

#SGPerspectives #Govsg
description_Translated:
Ive been in HR for most of my professional life. 

My career trajectory took a detour when I left my HR job in 2019 to move to China for 6 months with my family. We wanted to spend quality time before my son started formal primary education, experience a different culture, and also improve my Mandarin.

It wasnt an easy decision. I was concerned about our finances, my career, and if I could find a suitable job when we returned. My hands trembled when I handed in my resignation letter.

In China, I doubled down on networking efforts via online platforms. I took up online courses and volunteered with professional HR bodies.

It made all the difference when I returned. The CEO of an education technology company whom I knew contacted me about a HR leadership advisory role. But he also wanted me to head up digital marketing efforts.

This was completely new for me. I went for a Professional Conversion Programme with QED Consulting where I learnt about SEO, analytics, and using digital channels to create brand awareness.

I realised how important networking is in ones career. Nurture networks early, even before we need it. 

Learning is lifelong. You can pivot to other roles, even at a late age. 

You are always in control of your career.

- Martin Lee, in his 40s, Snr HR Advisor, Director of Partnerships at Edtech firm, The Amdon Group 

#SGPerspectives #Govsg

description:
â€œMy passion is in using technology to create innovative experiences for our community, including improving the lives of our elderly. That was why I started Dude Studio in 2010, a creative tech studio that has been evolving nearly every year with our most recent focus being developing Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) experiences. Building never seen before stuff excites me. 

In 2017, I developed a VR racing game for wheelchair-bound patients to have fun and to keep their minds active. A specially designed wheelchair is hooked up with sensors, so that the patient can navigate the VR game by turning the wheels. It took me close to five months to perfect the game.

Just a while before that, my friend suggested we bring my VR goggles to NTUC Health nursing home to engage the elderly residents there. The goggles transported viewers to a â€œvirtual universeâ€ via pre-recorded 360Â° videos, and they can look around by turning their heads. It was a hit with the residents and became the inspiration for me to start Mind Palace â€“ a not-for-profit social enterprise that uses customised VR technology to help dementia patients recall memories by immersing them in familiar places as a form of reminiscence therapy.

This month, weâ€™ve completed a boxing game which was first developed as an Instagram filter as a proof of concept. After a period of trial and error â€“ it finally worked. Itâ€™s currently deployed at 2 of NTUC Healthâ€™s elder care facilities. However, due to safe distancing measures, we canâ€™t be there to personally witness the Ah Gongs and Ah Mas playing our fitness game. We can only rely on the staff at the centres to send us videos of them playing the game.

I believe that digitalisation can empower the next generation to build projects in the digital space, especially for countries like Singapore where physical space can be an issue. I hope to continue creating innovative technologies that can help improve the lives of the elderly in our society.â€ 

- Eugene Soh, 30s, Founder of Dude Studio and Mind Palace

#SGPerspectives #TechForGood

Photo & write-up by: @plus_sg
description_Translated:
My passion is in using technology to create innovative experiences for our community, including improving the lives of our elderly. That was why I started Dude Studio in 2010, a creative tech studio that has been evolving nearly every year with our most recent focus being developing Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) experiences. Building never seen before stuff excites me. 

In 2017, I developed a VR racing game for wheelchair-bound patients to have fun and to keep their minds active. A specially designed wheelchair is hooked up with sensors, so that the patient can navigate the VR game by turning the wheels. It took me close to five months to perfect the game.

Just a while before that, my friend suggested we bring my VR goggles to NTUC Health nursing home to engage the elderly residents there. The goggles transported viewers to a virtual universe via pre-recorded 360 videos, and they can look around by turning their heads. It was a hit with the residents and became the inspiration for me to start Mind Palace  a not-for-profit social enterprise that uses customised VR technology to help dementia patients recall memories by immersing them in familiar places as a form of reminiscence therapy.

This month, weve completed a boxing game which was first developed as an Instagram filter as a proof of concept. After a period of trial and error  it finally worked. Its currently deployed at 2 of NTUC Healths elder care facilities. However, due to safe distancing measures, we cant be there to personally witness the Ah Gongs and Ah Mas playing our fitness game. We can only rely on the staff at the centres to send us videos of them playing the game.

I believe that digitalisation can empower the next generation to build projects in the digital space, especially for countries like Singapore where physical space can be an issue. I hope to continue creating innovative technologies that can help improve the lives of the elderly in our society. 

- Eugene Soh, 30s, Founder of Dude Studio and Mind Palace

#SGPerspectives #TechForGood

Photo & write-up by: @plus_sg

description:
After her Grandpa suffered from a stroke, grief-stricken Siti Muhassanah, 20, felt absolutely helpless and despondent as she did not know how to help him. She resolved to learn how to help others just like him. 

Siti, a Resident Care Associate at Ren Ci@Ang Mo Kio, is now pursuing an ITE Work-Study Diploma in Rehabilitation Care, empowering her to care for people like her grandfather, in their recovery process.

For information on opportunities in the healthcare sector: go.gov.sg/govsg-siti-ig

description:
Who should take the COVID-19 vaccines? Who should not? 

Infectious disease expert Dr Leong Hoe Nam helps some of our favourite local influencers @marklee4444 @syafiqapls @j.jaikishan @chiouhuey understand why some people are not eligible, while others are.

[Updated as of 31 May 2021] Singapore has revised eligibility guidelines for the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines to allow cancer patients on active treatment to be vaccinated but only in a hospital setting and after assessment by a doctor. 

For more information on the COVID-19 vaccines, visit www.igotmyshot.gov.sg

#covid19 #vaccinationSG #IGotMyShotSG @sgagsg @wahbananasg @kingkong.mp
description_Translated:
Who should take the COVID-19 vaccines? Who should not? 

Infectious disease expert Dr Leong Hoe Nam helps some of our favourite local influencers @marklee4444 @syafiqapls @j.jaikishan @chiouhuey understand why some people are not eligible, while others are.

description:
"Food waste is one of the biggest waste streams in Singapore. While a lot of work has been done to recycle and redistribute food, very few initiatives work towards preventing food waste to begin with.

I started Lumitics to help kitchens better manage their food waste. Very early on, I noticed that many kitchens, especially commercial ones, didnâ€™t track what was being thrown out. How can you begin to effectively reduce waste without first knowing how much waste you generate? 

At Lumitics, we decided to focus on helping hotels and airlines, as the scale of their operations would allow us make a more substantial impact. Together with a team of expert engineers, we designed and built our Insight food waste tracker from scratch. It uses a proprietary AI image recognition technology to accurately identify trash content. The data helps owners and kitchen staff understand what and how much is being thrown out, so that they can take steps to cut wastage and save costs.

It is very rewarding to see our clients make significant progress in reducing their waste generation â€“ some close to 40%! But we also owe a debt of gratitude to these clients, who have been supportive of Lumiticsâ€™ journey thus far. They provided constructive feedback which helped us to improve the design and efficacy of the Insight tracker. In many ways, our clients gave us the room to test our technology and fail many times too! 

Government grants and initiatives like the SG Green Plan will help shift the mindsets of businesses when it comes to sustainability. Being sustainable is no longer seen as a â€œgood to haveâ€, but a necessity. Singapore has much work to do to reach our sustainability goals and here at Lumitics, we want to be part of that change in a big way."

- Rayner Loi, 27, Co-founder & CEO of Lumitics

#SGperspectives #SGGreenPlan #ClimateActionSG #ClimateActionWeek

description:
Getting retrenched is probably the furthest thing from the mind of a young worker starting out in their career.

But for 28-year-old Asaad Fazah, it became a harsh reality in May last year.

But after a 5-month job hunt, and countless resumes and online courses, he got good news.

With the SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways programme, he was able to enrol in a traineeship, and pick up new skills in an industry he had no prior background in.

Watch his journey at go.gov.sg/resetplaylist

description:
â€œI started the social enterprise â€˜Happiness Initiativeâ€™ after noticing a gap in the preventive approaches towards mental health conditions in Singapore. I was fascinated about happiness & wellbeing, which prompted me to pursue further studies in the US that focused on life fulfilment & satisfaction. 

When we first introduced wellbeing programmes to schools in 2017, it wasnâ€™t easy. The education landscape wasnâ€™t ready. But in 2019, through a grant we received from the National Youth Council, we managed to raise awareness of the issue through a more entertaining medium â€“ film. That was how the Happiness Film Festival started. It was well-received. Tickets were sold out. People were willing to come onboard as panellists to discuss matters that were close to their hearts. 

When the pandemic hit us in early 2020, mental health issues were pushed to the forefront. People were worried about their livelihoods. Socialising became a challenge as we were confined at home. That was when we noticed schools beginning to take a more proactive approach towards mental health. 

We organised the Happiness Film Festival again in 2021, with a focus on six vulnerable groups â€” the elderly, people with intellectual disabilities, youth, underprivileged families, ex-offenders, & migrant workers. It was during a time when our migrant workers were not able to leave their dormitories due to the pandemic. Through film, the community started talking about these workers & their sacrifices, which encouraged a greater understanding of what they were facing.

The UNâ€™s World Happiness Report says Singapore has done well, but I believe there is still room for us to grow into a happier nation. We need to know what really drives us, & our sense of meaning and purpose. Other than spending time on our individual successes, how can we collectively take care of our community? 

I hope the Happiness Initiative will ensure wellbeing skills are accessible to everyone. When we look beyond ourselves and take care of people who are less fortunate than us, it will give us a greater sense of purpose.â€ #SGPerspectives

- Simon Leow, co-founder of Happiness Initiative, 40s

Photo & write-up by: @plus_sg

description:
â€œAll three generations of my family live under one roof. I believe that multi-generational relationships must be nurtured early. To encourage my children to bond with their grandparents, I ask them to play in my parentâ€™s room. That has created many conversations for them and opportunities to interact. If our family is out shopping, we encourage our kids to think of their grandparentâ€™s favourite food to buy back home for them! 

While the circuit breaker period in 2020 was a trying period being confined at home, it didnâ€™t stop us from bonding. Instead, we found things to do indoors, such as teaching the children how to grow plants. The kids, in turn, passed on their new-found skills to their grandparents.

One of my biggest parenting struggles is the difference in views between their grandparents and myself. However, they know that my wife and I are the ones who make the final decision. When we leave the children under our parentsâ€™ charge, we trust them to do what we agreed upon. For example, not buying them snacks or not letting them watch TV for more than two hours. We also remind our children of their boundaries, so that itâ€™s a shared responsibility.

I'm an advocate of filial piety and regularly share about my views on promoting positive family relationships. Aside from writing, I also love photography and Iâ€™m currently busy with my next photo book  project. Titled â€˜Grandparents, Cherish Them When They Are Still Aroundâ€™, the photo book captures sentimental moments of my children growing up with their grandparents. It's my contribution to a St Lukeâ€™s Hospital fundraising campaign to celebrate positive ageing and provide support for their beneficiaries. 

Having a strong family can be the support that helps us overcome a crisis and reminds us that there will always be someone behind us. There are few things that truly matter in life and family is one of them.â€

- Tan Chin Hock, healthcare professional, 44, a 2013 recipient of the Filial Piety award conferred by the Nanyang Confucian Association

#NationalFamilyWeek #SGPerspectives

.
They were around 18 years old when they met at work ğŸ‘©ğŸ»ğŸ§‘ğŸ»
.
â€œAt first, we were just friends,â€ Mdm Wu says, â€œI even introduced my female friend to him!â€
.
3 years laterâ€”at age 21â€”they married. 53 years on, the retired couple have 2 children and 4 grandchildren to call their own.
.
â€œSomething that most people donâ€™t know about my wife is that she didnâ€™t have an easy life when she was young,â€ Mr Loke says.
.
â€œWe went through difficult times in our earlier years of marriage, especially because we were constantly moving house. But these experiences have made our relationship strong over the years.â€
.
â€œIâ€™ve learned patience from her, and the importance of self-reflection,â€ Mr Loke shares. â€œMy philosophy for a long-lasting marriage? Think before you act. Take a step back, instead of being judgmental.â€
.
Mr Loke (75 years old) and Mdm Wu (74 years old) were guests at the inaugural Golden Jubilee Wedding Celebrations, earlier in March 2018 ğŸ‘°ğŸ»ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€âš–ï¸ ğŸ‰

description_Translated:
Mr Loke Yu Tong (75) and Mdm Wu So Har (74)
.
They were around 18 years old when they met at work 
.
At first, we were just friends, Mdm Wu says, I even introduced my female friend to him!
.
3 years laterat age 21they married. 53 years on, the retired couple have 2 children and 4 grandchildren to call their own.
.
Something that most people dont know about my wife is that she didnt have an easy life when she was young, Mr Loke says.
.
We went through difficult times in our earlier years of marriage, especially because we were constantly moving house. But these experiences have made our relationship strong over the years.
.
Ive learned patience from her, and the importance of self-reflection, Mr Loke shares. My philosophy for a long-lasting marriage? Think before you act. Take a step back, instead of being judgmental.
.
Mr Loke (75 years old) and Mdm Wu (74 years old) were guests at the inaugural Golden Jubilee Wedding Celebrations, earlier in March 2018  
.

description:
Did you know?

Ramadan is the month of the Holy Quran. Muslims fast during Ramadan. They are encouraged to do more good deeds, read the Quran and reflect on the values that it teaches.

The last 10 nights of Ramadan are especially significant for Muslims. Laylatul Qadr or the Night of Power is known to occur during this period. It is a night where past sins are erased and blessings are bountiful.

Fasting is one of the five pillars of Islam. It is meant to cultivate spiritual discipline. It cleanses oneâ€™s soul and instils compassion towards others. By feeling hungry and thirsty, itâ€™s easier to emphatise with the poor and the needy.

Wishing all our Muslim friends, Selamat Berpuasa! ğŸ•Œ

#ramadan #ramadankareem #ramadansg #sgramadan #hariraya #hariraya2019
description_Translated:
Did you know?

Ramadan is the month of the Holy Quran. Muslims fast during Ramadan. They are encouraged to do more good deeds, read the Quran and reflect on the values that it teaches.

The last 10 nights of Ramadan are especially significant for Muslims. Laylatul Qadr or the Night of Power is known to occur during this period. It is a night where past sins are erased and blessings are bountiful.

Fasting is one of the five pillars of Islam. It is meant to cultivate spiritual discipline. It cleanses ones soul and instils compassion towards others. By feeling hungry and thirsty, its easier to emphatise with the poor and the needy.

Wishing all our Muslim friends, Selamat Berpuasa!

description_Translated:
Are you ready for the biggest birthday party in town?  #NDP2018 is just about the corner! Think you know all about the past National Day Parades? Here're some fun facts you might not have known! 
. 
1. Fun Packs: The first fun pack giveaway started in 1991, as a plain old goodie bag containing essentials to help spectators cope with the weather. By 2007, there were 28 things in it! 
.
2. National Day Theme Songs: They only started in the 1980s. One of the first songs was 'Stand Up For Singapore', composed in 1984. How were crowds entertained before this? By a contingent of bagpipers! 
.
3. National Education Shows: Primary 5 school students started attending NDP rehearsals in 1997, as part of the National Education programme. 
.
4. Daytime Party: NDP was held in the daytime until 1973, when it became an evening event. 
. 
5. Red Lion: In 2014, Third Warrant Officer Shirley Ng became the first female Red Lion parachutist to make the jump at a NDP celebration!

Hidden Heroes of #NDP2018
.
 Khairul, 18, Singa mascot: I enjoy putting a smile on peoples faces. By the way, the Sharity mascot is the heaviest. This is the second-heaviest.
.
 Nirenj, Singapore Red Cross: Were all certified in First Aid, but what we need to pick up are things like the layout of the venue, escalation procedures, and who to look for in case of emergencies.
.
Wen Cong, 21, Volunteer: Not everyone can take part in this mass event, so Im very happy to have this chance. Its interesting to see how they coordinate everyone! Weve been practising since mid-May, on Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays.

description:
ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ Hidden Heroes of #NDP2018
.
ğŸˆAmelia, 17, Motivator: â€œItâ€™s my first time being a Motivator - I get to make new friends while celebrating the countryâ€™s birthday. At first, because Iâ€™m a bit shy, it was challenging to communicate. But Iâ€™ve learned how to be more open (and how to tie balloon sculptures!)â€
.
ğŸ˜œYong Liang, 29, Volunteer at the Media Relations Committee: â€œThis is my 8th NDP. What keeps me coming back is the people! Some of us have been volunteering together for years, 9 weeks at a time: 3 rehearsals, 3 National Education shows, 2 previews, and 1 actual day show.â€
.
ğŸ‘‹Janice, Usher: â€œWe practise different situations. For example, how to guide people to their platforms, how to encourage them not to leave seats in-between.â€
.
ğŸ‘‹Nick, 24, Usher: "It's my 5th time volunteering at the NDP. We're here every Saturday, since the combined rehearsals - from 10am to 10.30pm!"
.
ğŸ‘‹Joseph, 18, Usher: "It's hot but the spectators are really nice so it makes it all worth it."
description_Emoji: flag: Singapore, balloon, waving hand, winking face with tongue
description_Translated:
Hidden Heroes of #NDP2018
.
Amelia, 17, Motivator: Its my first time being a Motivator - I get to make new friends while celebrating the countrys birthday. At first, because Im a bit shy, it was challenging to communicate. But Ive learned how to be more open (and how to tie balloon sculptures!)
.
Yong Liang, 29, Volunteer at the Media Relations Committee: This is my 8th NDP. What keeps me coming back is the people! Some of us have been volunteering together for years, 9 weeks at a time: 3 rehearsals, 3 National Education shows, 2 previews, and 1 actual day show.
.
Janice, Usher: We practise different situations. For example, how to guide people to their platforms, how to encourage them not to leave seats in-between.
.
Nick, 24, Usher: "It's my 5th time volunteering at the NDP. We're here every Saturday, since the combined rehearsals - from 10am to 10.30pm!"
.
Joseph, 18, Usher: "It's hot but the spectators are really nice so it makes it all worth it."

Hidden Heroes of #NDP2018
.
 Raihan, 14, nEbO: Im happy because (as the youngest marcher for the NTUC contingent) I can feel what others feel when they perform. Im very proud to be in my first NDP together with my Aunt.
.

.
Nows your chance to catch Taufik Batisah and Hisyam Hamid flaunt their barbering skills in person! Join them, Adlina Adil, Fir Rahman, Yuslina Yussof, Sheiryn Aisiqa and the rest of the Gunting crew at this Meet & Greet session.
.

.

.

description:
Joanna Goy, (@singapore_lactation_bakes), 32: I'm a mum of three and an e-business owner, so I've got lots of bills and paper work ğŸ“„to manage. I like to have everything at a glance, so e-payments sure makes things a lot easier.
.
When our e-biz first started, we took only bank transfers and cash-on-delivery ğŸ’µ Accounting was really troublesome, as everything had to be manually keyed in! ğŸ’»
.
E-payment options benefit customers, but as an e-biz owner, there are several considerations â€“ first, the transactional fee, second, whether people would be open to use it, and third, whether it can be integrated into my site.
.

description_Translated:
Joanna Goy, (@singapore_lactation_bakes), 32: I'm a mum of three and an e-business owner, so I've got lots of bills and paper work to manage. I like to have everything at a glance, so e-payments sure makes things a lot easier.
.
When our e-biz first started, we took only bank transfers and cash-on-delivery  Accounting was really troublesome, as everything had to be manually keyed in! 
.
E-payment options benefit customers, but as an e-biz owner, there are several considerations  first, the transactional fee, second, whether people would be open to use it, and third, whether it can be integrated into my site.
.
We first started using PayPal and the response was really good. We now use  PayNow, Pay Anyone, PayLah! and PayPal every day for our online transactions and during our roadshows!
.

description:
Selamat Hari Raya Haji!
.
Also called the Great Day of Sacrifice, this is one of the holiest and greater of the two Hari Raya events in the Muslim calendar. Muslims in Singapore start the celebration by visiting the mosque in the morning, followed by paying respect at homes of elderly family members. Some Muslims also distribute sacrificed livestock such as sheep and lambs to those who are less fortunate.
.
Here's wishing a blessed and meaningful Hari Raya Haji to all our Muslim friends!
.
#hariraya #hariraya2017 #harirayahaji #harirayahaji2017 #korban #qurban #publicholidays #singapore
.

description:
Once in a blue moonâ€¦hey, that means tonight! ğŸ˜„ Lift your eyes to the skies this evening to see three lunar phenomena coincide! ğŸ¤©
.
One, a total lunar eclipse (where the Earth completely blocks the Sunâ€™s rays from lighting up the moon);
.
two, a supermoon (when the moon is as close to Earth as itâ€™ll ever be);
.
and three, a blue moon (the second full moon in a calendar month)!
.
The last time this happened in 1866, the telephone still wasnâ€™t invented yet! But today, you can take a selfie with this rare celestial event.
.

description:
#ICYMI: Just a week left to the end of the #WhatMakesSG photo contest! Check out judge @chiyin_Simâ€™s personal take on #WhatMakesSG. We want to hear your amazing stories too!
.
â€œThis is an all-too-familiar scene for me â€” I was on a bus at Changi Airport from the flight gate to the plane, catching yet another flight leaving Singapore. But that golden light that morning bathing the bus recast the whole scene for me. We might see Singapore with familiar eyes, and leaving sometimes allows us to look at home anew, but often too we can see beauty by stopping to take a step back to really SEE.
.
Show us your vision of Singapore!â€
.
Stand to win a National Geographic expedition trip or Canon cameras! More at www.WhatMakesSG.com. Contest â€ªends on 22 May.â€¬

#ICYMI: Just a week left to the end of the #WhatMakesSG photo contest! Check out judge @chiyin_Sims personal take on #WhatMakesSG. We want to hear your amazing stories too!
.
This is an all-too-familiar scene for me  I was on a bus at Changi Airport from the flight gate to the plane, catching yet another flight leaving Singapore. But that golden light that morning bathing the bus recast the whole scene for me. We might see Singapore with familiar eyes, and leaving sometimes allows us to look at home anew, but often too we can see beauty by stopping to take a step back to really SEE.
.
Show us your vision of Singapore!
.
Stand to win a National Geographic expedition trip or Canon cameras! More at www.WhatMakesSG.com. Contest ends on 22 May.

description:
Happy mid-week! This Wednesday, we visit Punggol. Also spelt as Ponggol, the name means "throwing sticks at branches of fruit trees to bring them down to the ground" in Malay.
.
The estate is home to one of Singapore's most recognisable landmarks, the 4.2 km long Punggol Waterway, as well as Pulau Serangoon, also known as Coney Island.
.

description:

.
Selegie is not just famous for tau huay. At one point in time, it boasted the tallest HDB complex comprising both shops and residential units. That honour went to Selegie House (pictured here) - launched in 1963 with the tallest block at 20 storeys. Selegie House is also a popular haunt for Instagrammers, especially near National Day.
.
Our #sgheartlands are full of instaworthy shots. Which are your favourite estates? Let us know by commenting below or tagging @gov.sg in your photos!

description:
TOOT-TOOT! Your pillow-y steamed rice cake, bursting with peanut-y or coconut-ty goodness, is ready!
.
The humble #tutukueh got its name from the sound made by the charcoal-heated steamers that were used to steam them.
.
This #localheritage snack was first brought to Singapore in the 1930s by a man named Tan Yong Fa, from Fujian, China. Originally called â€˜song gaoâ€™, they used to be made much larger, with no fillings.
.
And thatâ€™s your nugget of knowledge this #WorldHeritageDay!
.
Whatâ€™s your favourite filling? Are you #TeamPeanut, or #TeamCoconut?

description:
#Didyouknow before @singaporemci, there was MITA? The Ministry of Information and the Arts (MITA) was first established 27 years ago on this day (28 November)!
.
With the aim to keep Singaporeans informed about government policies and national issues, and to create a space for culture to flourish, MITA and in turn, its successor MCI, has been operating out of the rainbow-hued Old Hill Street Police Station since 2000. .

Interested to learn more about the Ministrys history? You can still catch a glimpse of the old MITA logo upon entering MCI along River Valley Road!

description:
Kallang, located in central Singapore, is a housing estate developed in 1959 around the Kallang River - Singaporeâ€™s longest river. The name â€œKallangâ€ was derived from the Malay term referring to the â€œorang lautâ€ or sea gypsies who lived nearby.
.
Kallang was home to Singapore's first airport, Kallang Airport, which was opened on 12 June 1937. Today, a signboard with the words "Kallang Airport" is standing at the junction of Old Airport Road and Cassia Link.
.
The estate also houses one of Singaporeâ€™s largest hawker centres, the Old Airport Road Food Centre.
.
#Kallang #OldAirportRoad #Singapore #KallangAirport #WalkaboutWednesday #ExploreSG

.
â€œFresh coats of paint at Singaporeâ€™s Sembcorp Marine Shipyards - When I think of Singapore, I think of the sea and itâ€™s maritime history going back centuries. I also arrived in Singapore by sail boat almost 40 years ago and started my career as a photographer here. This is why I am truly excited to be judging a new National Geographic photo competition with Gov.sg, #WhatMakesSG with some awesome prizes including a Nat Geo Photography Expedition to Yellowstone Park. I look forward to seeing your photography on what makes Singapore special to you.â€
.

description:
This week in 1983, the Singapore Civil Defence Force (@mySCDF) organised the very first Civil Defence Week. There were practical demonstrations, exhibitions, contests and even film shows to reinforce the Civil Defence message and this message still resonates till today. We have to stay united regardless of race or religion and stay committed to defending this country we all call home.
.
#FYI , every Saturday is Fire Station Open House from 9:00am to 11:00am.

description:
Founder of @bandofdoodlers, Mas Shafreen started The Band of Doodlers (BOD) as a way to keep connected with his art mentees and to have fun while enjoying their mutual passion for drawing. Now an 800-strong group of doodlers, BOD often gets commissioned to doodle for events and organisations such as Noise Singapore and Singapore Design Week. Most importantly, Mas takes pride in how BOD members keep to the ethos of non-exclusivity and helping each other out in the pursuit of art.
.
Thinking of chasing your own dreams? Heed Masâ€™s advice: â€œPursue your passion based on your happiness, not your talent. And donâ€™t procrastinate. One thing that people ironically procrastinate the most on is having fun.â€
.
#whitespacebandits #doodle #art #artwork #passion #singaporebrands #sgdesign

description:
Thinking of growing your own edible plants at home? Find out how at @nparksbuzzâ€™ #CommunityGardenFestival this weekend!
.
From today till Sunday, 9am-7pm at HortPark, be amazed by these delectable landscapes and plots, put together by some 300 community gardeners as well as award-winning local and international designers. You can also learn about the latest trends and techniques for edible gardening from experts and gardening enthusiasts.
.
Be sure not to miss the 3-metre tall Crimson Sunbird, made entirely of chillies, dragonfruit, long beans and more. Take a selfie with your friends and tag @gov.sg in your photos!
.
#sggarden #sggardening #gardening #sgfood #foodsg #food #hortpark

description:
There are 16 machines dedicated to sort all types of mail (letters, flats, packets), and about 400 staff working at the @mysingpost Mail Processing Centre to process the mail. Mail items with incomplete/incorrect/unreadable addresses will be stored in the Return Letters Unit for a period of 3 months for regular mail, and up to 6 months for registered mail. Thereafter, SingPost will assess if items are suitable for donation to charity or if they should be sent for destruction.
.
#writeyouraddressclearly #SingPost #Mail #Letters #snailmail #stamp #Singapore #exploresingapore #behindthescenes #yougotmail
.

.
LOF, as itâ€™s affectionately known, was born out of Lyndaâ€™s passion for fantasy tales and crafting things that made herself and others happy. It all started in 2004, in a little room in her parentsâ€™ place, with Lynda sleeping with all the T-shirts that she had printed for sale. Today, after 10 years of hard work, LOFâ€™s products have been featured in countless media outlets internationally.

description:
Singapore's original Satay Club is said to have started in the late 1940s off Beach Road. Customers sat on low stools and wooden benches to enjoy the popular local skewered meat dish. In the 1970s, it was moved to the Esplanade park. However, in 1994, the Satay Club stallholders had to re-locate due to redevelopment projects. The latest incarnation of the Satay Club, called "Satay by the Bay", is located at Gardens by the Bay.
.
@YipYewChong's "Satay Club" mural at 9A-13 Jalan Pinang
.
#MondayMural #SatayClub #SingaporeFood #Satay #food
.
ğŸ“¸: @decimalpoint

Located at Banda street, this mural depicts a grandmother and her grandchildren outside their house where she is pasting a red paper with the word â€œfuâ€ (which means â€˜good luckâ€™ in Mandarin) on the wall. description:
Fancy an enlarged take-away kopi bag? Check out @wheniwasfour_sg, a brand that sells quirky, local-flavoured lifestyle products inspired by childhood memories and day-to-day moments.
.
The business started out online with Li Ling and her two co-founders making 'five stones' plushies, before moving to other familiar Singaporean icons such as milo dinosaur and childhood candies. It wasnâ€™t all roses though â€“ they encountered many financial and space constraints when they first launched their business - but Li Ling and her co-founders persisted and managed to push through by balancing their online retail business with physical pop-up stores. Eventually, after saving enough cash, they fulfilled their dream of opening their very own physical store.
.
WHENIWASFOUR has managed to create simple but innovative designs such as handmade Ang Ku Kueh pins and Milo Dino cushion covers that capture the nostalgia of growing up in Singapore. That's why to Li Ling, â€œhappiness is always simple.â€
.
#singaporebrands #sgdesign #designedinsg #handmade #madeinsg #kopitakeaway #wheniwasfour_sg #wheniwasfour #kopidabaobag #waterloocentre

The #UnitedNations has set aside May 8 and 9 of each year to remember those who lost their lives during World War II. To commemorate this day, we share here a quote from the poem "For the Fallen", by English poet Laurence Binyon:
"They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old; 
Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. 
At the going down of the sun and in the morning, 
we will remember them."
#neverforget #ww2 #knowhistory #remembranceday #anzacday #theunknownsoldier #graveoftheunknownsoldier

description:
Kusu Island is one of Singapore's offshore Southern islands that you can explore by boat. It is located about 5.6 kilometres to the south of mainland Singapore.
.
Legend has it that a turtle transformed itself into the island to save two shipwrecked sailors - a Malay man and a Chinese man. That's how the island got its name because "Kusu" is "Turtle" or "Tortoise" in Chinese!
.
Every year, the Taoists will embark on a pilgrimage during the ninth month of the lunar calendar. The annual pilgrimage for this year began on Oct 20 and will end on Nov 17. The serene island also houses not one, but three Muslim 'keramat' (â€˜shrineâ€™ in Malay). Many devotees will climb the 152 steps leading to the shrines to pray for wealth, health, harmony, good marriage, even children (for the childless couples).
.
So if you need a quick getaway from the city, why not visit Kusu Island?
.
#DiscoverSG #ExploreSG #kusuisland #WalkaboutWednesday
.
ğŸ“¸: @nurash_x , @gwyndy_bird & Kang Sok Ling

description:
Do you know what it takes to keep our shorelines, waterways and beaches clean? Marine pollution not only harms the environment and marine life, but could also hamper navigational safety.
.
Thatâ€™s why every third Saturday of September is the official day of the International Coastal Cleanup (ICC). This year, some 3,500 volunteers from 80 organisations in Singapore took part.
.â€¨Yesterday (30 Sep), the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) organised a cleanup event to collect marine debris on kayaks. Volunteers from Republic Polytechic (RP) joined in as well. Through efforts such as these, we can all do our part for marine environment sustainability.
.
Donâ€™t water down the problem. Find out more at http://coastalcleanup.nus.edu.sg/
.
#ICCS #TrashFreeSeas #KeepSingaporeClean #EnvironmentalSustainability

Do you know what it takes to keep our shorelines, waterways and beaches clean? Marine pollution not only harms the environment and marine life, but could also hamper navigational safety.
.

.Yesterday (30 Sep), the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) organised a cleanup event to collect marine debris on kayaks. Volunteers from Republic Polytechic (RP) joined in as well. Through efforts such as these, we can all do our part for marine environment sustainability.
.

description:
Remember playing in the Bugis Junction fountain as a kid?
.
Opened on 8 September 1995, Bugis Junction is a pedestrian shopping mall made up of three streets - Malabar Street, Malay Street and Hylam Street. The old shophouses along these streets were rebuilt and weatherproofed, and the area covered with transparent glass domes to be air-conditioned. These "indoor streets" can be traced back to Singapore's earliest colonial history.
.
#ThrowbackThursday #TBT #Throwback

description:
Know the difference between Gundams and Patlabors? Or what Krillin and Monkey D. Luffy have in common? If you do, then you have to visit the Singapore Philatelic Museum today! Stand a chance at winning special collectibles by taking part in a fun quiz. Cosplayers from the Singapore Cosplay Club will also be around the museum dressed as your favourite anime characters. All this is part of the museumâ€™s â€œAnimania Sundayâ€ event. For more details, go to sg.sg/SPManimania.
.
You can also find out how Japanese pop culture has â€œstampedâ€ its mark on the philatelic world at the Anime X Stamps exhibition in the museum from now â€ªtill 15th April 2018â€¬. Over 9,000, I mean, 700 stamps from series such as One Piece, Neon Genesis Evangelion, Fate/Stay Night, Touken Ranbu, and Re:Zero will be on display as well!
.

Know the difference between Gundams and Patlabors? Or what Krillin and Monkey D. Luffy have in common? If you do, then you have to visit the Singapore Philatelic Museum today! Stand a chance at winning special collectibles by taking part in a fun quiz. Cosplayers from the Singapore Cosplay Club will also be around the museum dressed as your favourite anime characters. All this is part of the museums Animania Sunday event. For more details, go to sg.sg/SPManimania.
.

.

description:
#Didyouknow Holland Village had its own drama serial and that its iconic windmill was constructed in the early 2000s?
Now, have you ever wondered how the area got its name? It was actually named after Holland road, which was in turn named after Hugh Holland, an architect and amateur actor. Despite the name, neither the village nor the road was named after the Netherlands.
.
#ThrowbackThursday #TBT #Throwback #HollandVillage #Singapore
